awd_abstract_narration:
This award provides funding to help defray the expenses of participants in the "Great Plains Operator Theory Symposium," a conference series in which the 2020 event will take place during June 1-June 5, 2020, on the campus of Washington University in St. Louis.

From a modest beginning in 1981, the Great Plains Operator Theory Symposium has evolved into a major international conference on operator theory and operator algebra. This symposium focuses on recent developments in Operator Algebras and Operator Theory. Leading researchers will discuss important new developments and propose problems for future research. This symposium aims to be a conference covering broad areas with large participation, including many young people, who are encouraged to present their research. This award gives early career researchers, members of underrepresented groups, and researchers not funded by NSF an opportunity to attend and participate in this conference. The organizing committee will strive to make this funding opportunity widely known. More information will be made available at: http://www.math.wustl.edu/~ylsong/GPOTS.php

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
This award supported three conferences between 2020 and 2023, significantly contributing to the growth of functional analysis in the U.S. during and after the pandemic.

A virtual Great Plains Operator Theory Symposium (GPOTS) was held at Washington University in St. Louis from May 10-14, 2021. Over 150 participants from around the world attended this week-long conference. This event provided a much-needed forum for researchers, especially those in the early stages of their careers, to present and discuss their results during the pandemic.

An in-person GPOTS conference took place at Washington University in St. Louis from May 23-27, 2022. This was the first major in-person conference in functional analysis since the spring of 2020. Approximately 90 participants, mostly from North America, attended this week-long conference. The event covered a wide range of topics in operator theory and operator algebra, injecting a tremendous amount of energy into the new developments in functional analysis post-pandemic.

The Noncommutative Geometry Festival 2023 was held in person at Washington University in St. Louis from June 10-14, 2023. This conference maintained a very high standard in the field of noncommutative geometry and was the first international conference in this field since the pandemic. More than 50 researchers from around the world attended, presenting their recent research progress.


 


Last Modified: 06/03/2024
Modified by: Xiang Tang
